message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of lactose intolerance, which means that she cannot digest lactose properly. Magnesium hydroxide contains lactose and should be avoided in this patient. The other options are not related to lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, which can be worsened by Magnesium hydroxide, as it contains magnesium stearate that can bind to lactose and make it more difficult to digest. Cimetidine, sucralfate, and loperamide do not contain lactose and are not contraindicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, which can cause flatulence, abdominal cramping, and diarrhea after consuming milk or dairy products. Magnesium hydroxide can worsen these symptoms as it is an antacid that contains lactose. The other options are not likely to worsen the patient’s symptoms.
